statements.name: PROC HPFTEMPRECON
statements.description: The following options can be used in the PROC statement
statements.help:
PROC HPFTEMPRECON <options>;                 
	BY variables< /options>;                 
	BENCHID variableINTERVAL= interval< /options>;                 
	ID variable INTERVAL= interval< /options>;                 
	RECONCILE indicator<=benchmark></options>;

arguments.name: ACCDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the SAS data set that contains the BENCHACCUMULATION= option for each dependent variable listed in the _NAME_ variable

arguments.name: BENCHDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the SAS data set that contains the low-frequency series (benchmarks)

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the SAS data set that contains the high-frequency series

arguments.name: BENCHDIFF
arguments.description: specifies that the OUTFOR= data sets contain a variable named BENCHDIFF which is the difference between the reconciled predicted value and the input predicted value

arguments.name: OUTFOR=
arguments.description: names the output SAS data set to contain the reconciled values

arguments.name: OUTPROCINFO=
arguments.description: names the output data set to contain the summary information of the processing done by PROC HPFTEMPRECON

arguments.name: OUTSTAT=
arguments.description: names the output data set to contain the statistics of fit (or goodness-of-fit statistics)

arguments.name: BENCHACCUMULATION=
arguments.description: specifies how the data of the high-frequency series is accumulated within each BENCHID time period of the low-frequency series

arguments.name: BIASCORRECTION=
arguments.description: specifies the type of bias correction to apply to the indicator series

arguments.name: BENCHCONS=
arguments.description: specifies whether the full range of the data in the DATA= data set or only the range covered by the data in BENCHDATA= should be used in the reconciliation process. The default is BENCHCONS=NOSTRICT, which corresponds to all data being used.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of iterations performed by the quadratic solver

arguments.name: PREDICTONLY
arguments.description: specifies that only the predicted value be modified

arguments.name: SCALEEXP=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the exponent of the scaling factor

arguments.name: SIGN=
arguments.description: specifies the sign constraint on the reconciled series

arguments.name: SMOOTH=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the autoregressive smoothing parameter

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC to obtain separate analyses for groups of observations defined by the BY variables

statements.name: BENCHID
statements.description: names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the BENCHDATA= data set

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations
arguments.help: ALIGN=BEGINNING | BEG | B | MIDDLE | MID | M | ENDING | END | E

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the end of the data

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS format used for the DATE variable in the output data sets

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: specifies the frequency of the low-frequency time series

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: specifies how missing values are assigned in the time series of low-frequency forecasts
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | AVG | MINIMUM | MIN | MEDIAN | MED | MAXIMUM | MAX | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | PREV | NEXT | *number*

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the beginning of the data

arguments.name: TRIMMISS=
arguments.description: specifies how missing values are trimmed from the time series of low-frequency forecasts

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: specifies how leading and trailing zero values are interpreted in the time series of low-frequency forecasts

statements.name: ID
statements.description: names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input and output data sets for the high-frequency series in the DATA= data set and the reconciled series in the OUTFOR= data set

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations
arguments.help: ALIGN=BEGINNING | BEG | B | MIDDLE | MID | M | ENDING | END | E

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the end of the data

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS format used for the DATE variable in the output data sets

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: specifies the frequency of the indicator time series

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: specifies how missing values are assigned in the time series of high-frequency forecasts
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | AVG | MINIMUM | MIN | MEDIAN | MED | MAXIMUM | MAX | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | PREV | NEXT | *number*

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the beginning of the data

arguments.name: TRIMMISS=
arguments.description: specifies how missing values are trimmed from the time series of high-frequency forecasts

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: specifies how leading and trailing zero values are interpreted in the time series of high-frequency forecasts

statements.name: RECONCILE
statements.description: enables you to specify custom names for a group of variables to be reconciled and identify the role each of those variables plays in the reconciliation process

arguments.name: ACTUAL=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable in the DATA= data set that contains the actual values

arguments.name: LOWER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable in the DATA= data set that contains the lower confidence limit values

arguments.name: UPPER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable in the DATA= data set that contains the upper confidence limit values

arguments.name: STD=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable in the DATA= data set that contains the standard error values
